byline.original: By PATRICK HEALY and JONATHAN MARTIN

abstract: Republican establishment is grappling with growing fear of historic split within party, as disgruntled working class Republicans demand presidential nominee who represents their interests; common voters are expressing concerns about immigration, wages and demographic changes that are at odds with establishment candidates' focus on free trade, reduced taxes and openness to immigration; split, which feels markedly different than past inter-party skirmishes, could sway election results.
lead_paragraph: In an election campaign with a different, angry feel, the party’s establishment is facing a people’s coup.

headline.main: For Republicans, Mounting Fears of Lasting Split
headline.print_headline: For Republicans, Fears of a Lasting Split as Class Divisions Erupt

snippet: In an election campaign with a different, angry feel, the party’s establishment is facing a people’s coup.
